title: Frequently Asked Questions
description: Naturopathic Physicians diagnose, treat, and support prevention of disease using a system of practice based on the natural healing capacity of individuals and includes counseling to improve health related behaviors. Naturopathic physicians may use physiological, psychological or mechanical methods. They may also use natural medicines, prescription or legend drugs, foods,
cleaned_text: treat, and support prevention of disease using a system of practice based on the natural healing capacity of individuals and includes counseling to improve health related behaviors. Naturopathic physicians may use physiological, psychological or mechanical methods. They may also use natural medicines, prescription or legend drugs, foods, herbs, or other natural remedies. Reported job titles include: Naturopathic Physician, Naturopathic Doctor, Physician, Doctor of Naturopathic Medicine. ] [Naturopathic oncology is the application of the art and science of naturopathic medicine to the field of cancer care and treatment. Naturopathic oncologists work both in hospital oncology settings and in private practices, bringing their wisdom, perspective and experience to aid oncology treatment teams that seek the best positive outcomes for their patients.] [The Oncology Association of Naturopathic Physicians (OncANP) is a society of physicians who either specialize in naturopathic oncology or who desire to further their knowledge and understanding of the field. OncANP is an affiliate of the American Association of Naturopathic Physicians (AANP). OncANP's founding vision is, " to enhance survival and quality of life for people living with cancer through the integration of naturopathic oncology into cancer care." One of the goals of the OncANP is to bring naturopathic doctors into standard medical oncology practices. To achieve this, the organization has worked to create a credentialing process to assure a level of competence in naturopathic oncology.] [Naturopathic Oncologists: The OncANP initiated a credentialing process for naturopathic doctors in 2006. A separate and independent board, the American Board of Naturopathic Oncology (ABNO) was established to oversee the process. ABNO established a Board of Medical Examiners (BoMEx). ABNOBoMEx developed standards including training requirements, an application process and mechanisms for an independent agency to administer board certification tests.] [FABNO](http://www.fabno.org/) (Fellow of the American Board of Naturopathic Oncology): Naturopathic physicians who meet standards representative of advanced experience and knowledge in cancer care are eligible for board certification in Naturopathic Oncology. Qualifying doctors whose applications are accepted must completed a 2-year residency focused in naturopathic oncology or have been in practice for at least 5 years with 5000 pt contact hours and submit cases for review by designated examiners. All applicants must then pass a board certification exam in order to be awarded the status of Fellow by the American Board of Naturopathic Oncology. Fellows of the American Board of Naturopathic Oncology (FABNO's) meet the highest standard of the profession as specialists in naturopathic oncology. [The Need for Naturopathic Oncology?] Many people with cancer choose complementary and alternative medicine in their fight against cancer and in seeking to improve quality of life while undergoing treatment for cancer. They utilize therapies including meditation, prayer, acupuncture, herbal, botanical, nutritional diets, homeopathic, and other holistic practices seeking benefit. Naturopathic doctors specializing in oncology serve as capable guides for patients interested in exploring alternative medicine. Naturopathic doctors (ND) support people with cancer to use natural therapies safely and seek to maximally support overall health, fight disease processes, and prevent or reduce side effects of standard cancer treatment regimens for patients who utilize them. ND's promote and teach health related behaviors and may recommend specific supplements or nutritional programs in an individualized treatment approach. ND's are trained at accredited naturopathic medical schools in modern scientific nature cure. Please refer to the AANP at naturopathic.org for more information on the education and training of naturopathic doctors. Naturopathic doctors who specialize in naturopathic oncology understand both the standard treatments employed by medical oncologists and how best to work in a collaborative model of cancer co-treatment. They often help patients maintain their oncology treatment regimens and provide vital support for reducing side effects of those treatments. Naturopathic doctors are well aware of the multitude of 'alternative therapies' promoted to cure cancer and work to educate patients on evidence based treatment modalities. Naturopathic physicians may offer advanced alternative therapies to their patients including things such as intravenous treatments and hyperthermia therapies. You're applying for a research grant! Congratulations. Here are some resources to help you get started: |Refine your research idea and formulate a question:|| |[How to plan and write a budget for a research grant proposal - Journal of Ayurveda and Integrative Medicine](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0975947617301328) [Turning your research idea into a proposal worth funding - Salmaan Kanji](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4690671/) [Best practices in Equity, Diversity and Inclusion in Research](https://www.sshrc-crsh.gc.ca/funding-financement/nfrf-fnfr/edi-eng.aspx) Case report: [Case report writing for NDs (Seely & Leung)](https://storage.oncanp.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/13015242/Seely-Case-report-writing-for-NDs.pdf) [Guidelines to case report writing for naturopathic doctors](http://www.bcna.ca/wp/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/CasereportsforNDs.pdf)(BCNA) [Integrative medicine case reports: A clinicians' guide to publication](http://worldnaturopathicfederation.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/AIMED-case-studies.pdf)(World Naturopathic Foundation) [A guide to writing case reports for the Journal of Medical Case Reports and BioMed Central Research Notes](https://jmedicalcasereports.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1752-1947-7-239)(Ryson R, 2013) Case series: [Integrative medicine case series: A clinician's guide to publication](http://worldnaturopathicfederation.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/AIMED-case-series.pdf)(World Naturopathic Foundation) Retrospective chart [The chart review: important methodological considerations](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3853868/)(Vassar & Holzman, 2013) [Chart Review Guidelines and Instructions | Research & Innovation](https://www.ualberta.ca/research/research-support/research-ethics-office/human-research-ethics/information-and-data/health-information/chart-review.html)(University of Alberta) Systematic reviews and Meta-analyses: - Prospective registry of systematic reviews - [PROSPERO](https://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO/) [NIH Systematic Review Protocols and Protocol Registries](https://www.nihlibrary.nih.gov/services/systematic-review-service/systematic-review-protocols-and-protocol-registries) [Systematic reviews in integrative medicine: A clinician's guide to publication](http://worldnaturopathicfederation.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/AIMED-Systematic-review.pdf)(World Naturopathic Foundation) [Meta-analysis in systematic reviews of complementary and integrative medicine trials Advances in Integrative Medicine](http://worldnaturopathicfederation.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/AIMED-Meta-Analyses.pdf)(World Naturopathic Foundation) Pilot/feasibility studies: [CONSORT pilot of pilot study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5716817/)(In J, 2017) Program evaluations: [Program evaluation toolkit](https://www.nccmt.ca/knowledge-repositories/search/68)(National Collaborating Centre for Methods and Tools) [10-step process for developing an evaluation plan](https://www.publichealthontario.ca/-/media/documents/A/2015/at-a-glance-10step-evaluation.pdf?la=en)(Public Health Agency of Canada) Surveys/questionnaires: [Considerations when developing a survey](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5325124/)(Safdar et al, 2017) [Planning and conducting a survey](https://www.bmj.com/about-bmj/resources-readers/publications/epidemiology-uninitiated/5-planning-and-conducting-survey)(British Medical Journal) [Questionnaire Design Tip Sheet](https://psr.iq.harvard.edu/book/questionnaire-design-tip-sheet)(Harvard University) - Book: Designing and Conducting Health Surveys: A Comprehensive Guide 3rd edition by Lu Ann Aday, Llewellyn J. Cornelius How will you get your research findings out into the world and ensure they are read? The two most common methods of dissemination are publication in a peer-reviewed journal and presentation at conferences. Conferences: Conferences may provide the opportunity to present your findings orally or in a research poster format. Below are some conference to consider (there are many others!): [Oncology Association of Naturopathic Physicians](https://oncanp.org/)- Research poster session and oral sessions available. Please submit! - Society for Integrative Oncology (SIO) conference - [https://integrativeonc.org/conference](https://integrativeonc.org/conference) - International Society of Traditional, Complementary and Integrative Medicine Researchers (ISCMR) - (held biannually) - [https://iscmr.org/](https://iscmr.org/) - Interdisciplinary Network of CAM Researchers (INCAM) (Canadian chapter of ISCMR) (held biannually) [https://iscmr.org/content.aspx?page_id=22&club_id=869917&module_id=378920](https://iscmr.org/content.aspx?page_id=22&club_id=869917&module_id=378920) - American Association of Naturopathic Physicians conference - [https://naturopathic.org/](https://naturopathic.org/) - Canadian Association of Psychosocial Oncology (CAPO) conference - [https://www.capo.ca/](https://www.capo.ca/) - Hawaii Doc Talks - [https://www.events.syncopatemeetings.com/hawaii-doc-talks/](https://www.events.syncopatemeetings.com/hawaii-doc-talks/), [https://www.facebook.com/Hawaiidoctalks/](https://www.facebook.com/Hawaiidoctalks/) - International Congress on Naturopathic Medicine - [http://icnmnaturopathy.eu/en/](http://icnmnaturopathy.eu/en/) - Provincial and state conferences (e.g. OAND, AZNMA, BCNA) Journal publication Journals have specific scopes and submission requirements. It is recommended to consider the journal you might want to publish in early in the development process so you can ensure your study will meet their requirements. There are hundreds of peer-reviewed journals to consider, both Medline indexed and not. Below are a handful of journals with scopes related to integrative/complementary medicine and/or cancer care. Medline indexed journals: - The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine - [https://home.liebertpub.com/publications/journal-of-alternative-and-complementary-medicine-the/26/overview](https://home.liebertpub.com/publications/journal-of-alternative-and-complementary-medicine-the/26/overview) - Journal of Complementary and Alternative Medical research: [https://www.journaljocamr.com/index.php/JOCAMR/about/submissions](https://www.journaljocamr.com/index.php/JOCAMR/about/submissions) - Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: [https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ecam/guidelines/](https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ecam/guidelines/) - Supportive care in Cancer - [https://www.springer.com/journal/520](https://www.springer.com/journal/520) - Nutrition: [https://nutritionj.biomedcentral.com/submission-guidelines/preparing-your-manuscript](https://nutritionj.biomedcentral.com/submission-guidelines/preparing-your-manuscript) - and therapies: [https://bmccomplementmedtherapies.biomedcentral.com/](https://bmccomplementmedtherapies.biomedcentral.com/) Professional publications and non-Medline indexed journals: - Natural Medicine Journal (Journal of the AANP) - Vital Link (Journal of the CAND) - Provincial or State association journals (e.g. The Pulse - Journal of the OAND) - Naturopathic doctor news and review (NDNR) Other forms of dissemination: - News releases - Social media posts - Talks/lectures at local cancer groups or hospitals Paper: [Preparing and Publishing a Scientific Manuscript](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5405644/) (Jirge, 2017) Review the reporting guidelines for your study type - Clinical trials - [CONSORT 2010 Statement: updated guidelines for reporting parallel group randomized trials](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/consort/) - There are specialized guidelines for pilot/feasibility trials, herbal medicine, acupuncture, non-pharmacological interventions, and many others. All are available through the above link. - Observational studies - [The Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) Statement: guidelines for reporting observational studies](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/strobe/) - There are specific guidelines for cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies. All are available through the above link - Case reports: [The CARE Guidelines: Consensus-based Clinical Case Reporting Guideline Development](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/care/) - Systematic reviews / meta-analyses: [Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses: The PRISMA Statement](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/prisma/) - More reporting guidelines: [The EQUATOR Network | Enhancing the QUAlity and Transparency Of Health Research](https://www.equator-network.org/) Be sure to consider what journal(s) you might want to submit to as you are writing, as journals have specific scopes and submission requirements. Prior to initiating a research project, consider the cost of the study to ensure it's feasible with or without funding. Beyond the direct costs of conducting research (e.g. statistical software, purchasing full-text papers, filing cabinets for storage), consider the time spent developing a protocol, analyzing and interpreting results, and writing and editing manuscripts for submission. Potential costs include: - Personal time spent creating a protocol, executing the project, analyzing results, manuscript writing - Storage fees, filing cabinets - Consulting fees for statistician, librarian - REB/IRB review (if not affiliated with the institution) - Statistical software (most common: IBM SPSS) - Publication costs - will vary but can range from $1000-3000 for open access, higher-impact journals To help off-set costs, many researchers will seek funding opportunities. While funding opportunities exist, many are highly competitive with large institutions competing for limited funds. Here is a useful paper: [How to plan and write a budget for a research grant proposal?](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0975947617301328) (Patil S, 2019) Below are some grants that NDs and ND students might consider if their project necessitates funding. Please let the research committee know of other opportunities you are aware of so we can add them! |Name||Additional information||Link if applicable| |OncANP Research members. $2,000 USD grant awarded bi-annually.|| | Will consider foreign organizations proposal, see website for requirements. There are aspects of research that NDs might need help with, including protocol development, IRB/REB submissions, data management, and statistical analysis. You can hire research consultants to help with the aspects you are not able to complete on your own. NUNM offers research consulting: [Contract Research](https://nunm.edu/research/contract/) Many universities and hospitals offer research methods consulting services, however, in many cases, you or someone on the team must be affiliated with the institution. You can contact local universities/research methods centres to find out. Regulatory and ethical approval is most often granted from Research Ethics Boards (REB)/Institutional Review Boards (IRB), or from federal agencies such as Health Canada or the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Regulatory approval from Health Canada or the FDA are only required for regulated interventional trials (e.g. phase 1-4 clinical trials). These types of studies are generally too complex to be run by NDs in practice; they require a larger study team and usually affiliation with a university or hospital. Therefore, they will not be discussed. When to submit for REB/IRB approval? Generally, all studies other than case reports must obtain ethical approval from an REB/IRB. On the other hand, Quality Improvement (QI) activities generally do not. There can be some overlap and confusion between what constitutes research versus quality improvement. There are many resources online with tools for determining if your project is research or QI, here is an example: [Quality Improvement vs Research - Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Research Institute](https://irb.research.chop.edu/quality-improvement-vs-research) Who to submit to? If you work for or are affiliated with an institution (e.g. university, college, hospital), or the research will be conducted at an institution, or the research subjects will be recruited from an institution, you will generally be required to submit to the REB/IRB from that institution. Many REBs/IRBs will not review studies for independent researchers (meaning you have no affiliation with the institution). Both CCNM REB and NUNM REB will accept applications from independent researchers for a fee. REB/IRBs you might consider: Canadian College of Naturopathic Medicine (CCNM) [Ethical Conduct of Research Involving Humans](https://www.ccnm.edu/research/research-policies/ethical-conduct-research-involving-humans) - Will review external research National University of Natural Medicine (NUNM) [Contract Research](https://nunm.edu/research/contract/) [Institutional Review Board - National University of Natural Medicine](https://nunm.edu/research/resources/irb/) - Will review external research Bastyr University [Bastyr University Research](https://bastyr.edu/research) - Does not review external research. Principal investigator must be affiliated with Bastyr. Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine (SCNM) [IRB/RAB Forms | IRB](https://my.scnm.edu/ICS/Research/IRB/) - Does not review external research. Principal investigator must be a SCNM faculty member or staff National University of Health Sciences (NUHS) [Institutional Review Board](https://www.nuhs.edu/research/starting-your-research/institutional-review-board/) - Does not review external research. Principal or co-investigator must be a member of NUHS faculty Private or external IRB/REBs Advarra and WCG IRB are two examples of external IRB/REBs offering services in Canada and the US - [https://www.advarra.com/irb-services/](https://www.advarra.com/irb-services/) and [https://www.wcgirb.com](https://www.wcgirb.com) Most types of research require that you complete specific training to ensure safe and ethical treatment of participants. The only type of research that does not typically require research training are reviews (narrative, systematic, meta-analyses) and case reports. Please be aware that there is additional training beyond what is listed below for regulated interventional trials, however this is beyond the scope of this research toolkit. Note: Always check requirements for your specific location, Institutional review board/Research Ethics Board, and if relevant, your academic institution. Canada: |Name||Brief description||Link if applicable||When - TriCouncil Policy Statement||TCPS2 is a Canadian guideline for the ethical conduct of research involving humans and/or human biological materials.|| | [https://about.citiprogram.org/en/series/good-clinical-practice-gcp/](https://about.citiprogram.org/en/series/good-clinical-practice-gcp/) *Always choose a training option that offers a certificate of completion, save a copy. HIPPA training United States: |Name||Brief |Human Subjects Research Training||Guideline for the ethical conduct of research involving humans and/or human biological materials.||Available through several organizations, including Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI) and the NIH - most educational and research institutions have accounts. | One option for online training: |Required for all research and quality improvement involving human subjects||Takes about 3 hours to complete | *Always choose a training option that offers a certificate of completion, save a copy. |GCP: Good Clinical Practice||GCP training describes the responsibilities of investigators, sponsors, monitors, and REBs in the conduct of clinical trials. It ensures the rights, safety, and well-being of human subjects are protected, trials are conducted in accordance with approved plans, and data derived from clinical trials are reliable.||Several organizations offer training. | Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI) - most educational and research institutions have accounts for this. Free GCP Training options: |Required for any interventional trial||Takes about 6 hours to complete | *Always choose a training option that offers a certificate of completion, save a copy. |Protocol and SOP training||Ensures anyone involved in a study is aware of study procedures outlined in the protocol and SOPs, if applicable. SOPs are detailed step-by-step instructions for specific aspects of a study, typically more detailed than what would be found in a protocol.||N/A||Required for any study with a protocol and standard operating procedures||The researcher may read the materials and sign a training log, or may be taken through a training presentation from the study team| |HIPPA training and knowledge||Privacy training||N/A||Required for all research involving human subjects.||Academic institutions will often have their own training process, the privacy training for being a healthcare provider may be sufficient.| Every clinical investigation begins with the development of a research protocol. A protocol includes information on the background, rationale, objectives, design, methodology, and project organization. Protocols should be developed for all study types with the exception of case reports. There are many different formats; if you work with an institution you should ask if they have specific requirements and templates. Reporting guidelines: Reporting guidelines are available for most study types. Reviewing these as you are developing your protocol is helpful to ensure you are setting yourself up to conduct your study properly and write a great manuscript. The guidelines have checklists available for a quick review of elements you should be including and planning for. See the manuscript wiring section for more details. - Standard Protocol Items - Recommendations for Interventional Trials - [SPIRIT Statement](https://www.spirit-statement.org/) - Provides recommendations for the minimum content of a clinical trial protocol - The 33 item check-list takes you through items that should be included - Even if you are not doing an interventional trial, this is still a useful checklist to consult as many of the sections will still be relevant. - Observational studies - [The Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) Statement: guidelines for reporting observational studies](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/strobe/) - Case reports: [The CARE Guidelines: Consensus-based Clinical Case Reporting Guideline Development](https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/care/) - Systematic reviews / meta-analyses: - Other reporting guidelines: [The EQUATOR Network | Enhancing the QUAlity and Transparency Of Health Research](https://www.equator-network.org/) Templates and other resources: - Paper: [Protocol Writing in Clinical Research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5198475/)(Al-Jundi & Sakka, 2016) - Sample protocol templates: - University of Alberta - Observational and interventional trial protocol templates [Tools & Templates | Research & Innovation](https://www.ualberta.ca/research/research-support/quality-management-in-clinical-research/tools-templates.html) - University of California San Francisco - [Clinical Trial Protocol Development](https://hub.ucsf.edu/protocol-development) - University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine - [Retrospective review protocol template](https://irb.upenn.edu/sites/default/files/ProtocolTemplate_Retrospective_Final_201502.doc) - University of South Florida - [Retrospective chart review protocol template](https://health.usf.edu/-/media/Files/Medicine/Research/OCR/protocoltemplateChartReviews081108sa.ashx?la=en&hash=38E70A2C0B6A5088B1DEF2D41D7C207697CC3248) - National Institutes of Health - [NIH Systematic Review Protocols and Protocol Registries](https://www.nihlibrary.nih.gov/services/systematic-review-service/systematic-review-protocols-and-protocol-registries) - University of Alberta - Observational and interventional trial protocol templates - How to do high-quality clinical research: first steps (Sandercock & Whiteley, 2018) [Click here for paper](https://storage.oncanp.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/13015242/Sandercock-How-to-do-high-quality-clinical-research-part-1.pdf) - Research questions, hypotheses, and objectives (Farrugia, 2009) [Click here for paper](https://storage.oncanp.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/13015242/Farrugia-Research-questions-hypotheses-and-objectives.pdf) - Developing research questions - [Research Questions - Research Guides at Queen's University](https://guides.library.queensu.ca/clinical-trials/research-questions) Clinical Trial: Any investigation involving participants that evaluate the effects of one or more health-related interventions on health outcomes. In a clinical trial, participants are prospectively assigned interventions according to a pre-defined protocol. This includes pilot studies and single-arm trials, non-randomized controlled trials, and randomized controlled trials. - e.g., you have developed a new drug for Parkinson's Disease and want to see how effective it is. You enroll people and give them your intervention. Observational Trial: The study of human acts or behaviours in which people involved in their normal activities are observed by researchers who participate in some way with the activity. Participants in the study may receive therapeutic, diagnostic, or other interventions, but the investigator does not assign interventions to the study participants. - e.g., you wish to know if more frequent medical imaging results in lower recurrence rates for breast cancer, so you collect data from breast cancer patients at your local institution. Qualitative Research: An approach that aims to understand how people think about the world and how they act and behave in it. Data collection may include interviews, direct observation, and focus groups, and the data is usually non-numerical. - e.g., you wish to know why people seek naturopathic care at your clinic so you conduct structured interviews with them at various time points and record your findings. Quality Improvement: A process of systematic, data-guided activities that involves implementing knowledge or evaluating/improving a process or program through established/accepted standards. Quality improvement is designed to bring about immediate, positive changes in the delivery of healthcare in a particular setting. - e.g., you identify that 50% of your patients miss appointments on average, so you develop a new policy to conduct reminder phone calls for each patient the day prior to their appointment. You then evaluate the rate of missed appointments before and after your policy was implemented and report your findings. Medical chart reviews - Uses patient data from charts to answer a research question. They can be retrospective (uses pre-recorded patient data), or prospective (plans to evaluate patient data that does not yet exist). - e.g., you want to see if there is a difference in outcomes among patients you have seen with metastatic pancreatic cancer who utilized subcutaneous mistletoe versus those who did not. You are using data that is already recorded to conduct this retrospective chart review. Systematic Review: a review of the evidence on a clearly formulated question that uses explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant primary research, and to extract and analyze data from the studies that are included in the review. - e.g., you hire a medical librarian to conduct a search of all RCTs studying melatonin and the reduction of mortality for people with lung cancer and conduct an analysis on all the available data. Traditional Literature (Narrative) Review: A comprehensive, critical, and objective analysis of the current knowledge on a topic. Narrative reviews describe and appraise previous work but do not describe the specific methods by which the reviewed studies were identified, selected, and evaluated. - e.g., you wish to describe the procedures of administering hyperthermia for people with breast cancer, so you conduct a search for any related studies and summarize their work. (Thank you to Mark Legacy, Clinical Research Assistant at the Centre for Health Innovation for this section) The following websites provide information, resources, or online training for developing and conducting research - Research Fundamentals: Preparing You to Successfully Contribute to Research - [free online training course](https://www.pcori.org/engagement/research-fundamentals)developed in partnership with the American Institutes for Research - World Naturopathic Foundation - [Research Writing Tools](http://worldnaturopathicfederation.org/research-writing-tools/) [The EQUATOR Network | Enhancing the QUAlity and Transparency Of Health Research](https://www.equator-network.org/) [National Collaborating Centre for Methods and Tools: Home](https://www.nccmt.ca/) [Institute of Translational Health Sciences (ITHS)](https://www.iths.org/investigators/handbook/) Conferences, webinars, and other interactive resources offer a unique learning experience that involves a human touch. It can provide you with the opportunity to explore others' opinions, network with new colleagues, and interact with new people to help answer your questions, while also receiving feedback. Provided below are different resources and organizations which host different interactive learning opportunities periodically. Conference Hosts: - OncANP: [https://oncanp.org/](https://oncanp.org/) - Society for Integrative Oncology - San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium (SABCS): [https://www.sabcs.org/](https://www.sabcs.org/) - American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR): [https://www.aicr.org/](https://www.aicr.org/) - Canadian Interdisciplinary Network of Complementary Medicine [https://www.iscmr.org/content.aspx?page_id=22&club_id=869917&module_id=372144](https://www.iscmr.org/content.aspx?page_id=22&club_id=869917&module_id=372144) Webinars: - OncANP Webinars [https://integrativeonc.org/knowledge-center/sio-webinars](https://integrativeonc.org/knowledge-center/sio-webinars) Interactive Resources: OncANP Journal Club Journal clubs provide an opportunity to critically appraise papers, learn how to apply research findings in clinical practice, and discuss papers with colleagues. The OncANP offers 4-6 journal clubs yearly, with different presenters. Check your inbox or OncANP website for the next one! OncANP Group Chat A place to ask clinical questions, share recent research, and communicate in an informal setting with other OncANP members Research databases offer users curated and organized information/studies to help connect them with the resources they need to answer the questions they have. Database preference is often user-dependent and will depend on the specific question you are trying to answer and your preferred style of data organization. We invite you to explore the following databases to find which one(s) best suits your needs and style of information presentation/organization. KNOW Database: [https://www.knowintegrativeoncology.org/](https://www.knowintegrativeoncology.org/) Access comes with OncANP paid membership. Provides users with detailed summaries of relevant integrative oncology research. Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) Database: [https://www.tripdatabase.com/](https://www.tripdatabase.com/) Both free and paid accounts/memberships are available. A clinical search engine to help support research evidence in practice. Natural Medicines: [https://naturalmedicines.therapeuticresearch.com/](https://naturalmedicines.therapeuticresearch.com/) Majority of content is reserved for paid members. Provides users with interaction checking, detailed reviews of natural health products (effectiveness, dose, safety, etc.) and other relevant information for NDs. Examine.com: [https://examine.com/](https://examine.com/) Both free and paid content/accounts available. Provides users with detailed summaries of different natural health products and conditions, with a focus on evidence rating/quality. PubMed: [https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) A free database containing over 32 million citations and studies. Contains a mix of open-access and paid content. Education Resources Information Center (ERIC): [https://eric.ed.gov/](https://eric.ed.gov/) A free service to find research and publications pertaining to academic, education and/or policy content. Directory of Open Access Journals: [https://doaj.org/](https://doaj.org/) A free search engine tool to find open access journals and articles. A) Center for Evidence-Based Medicine: Critical Appraisal Tools The Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine, facilitated by Oxford University, provides a comprehensive list of critical appraisal worksheets to help you appraise studies you come across. ( [https://www.cebm.ox.ac.uk/resources/ebm-tools/critical-appraisal-tools](https://www.cebm.ox.ac.uk/resources/ebm-tools/critical-appraisal-tools)) B) Evidence Based Medicine Calculators This website ( [https://ebm-tools.knowledgetranslation.net/calculator](https://ebm-tools.knowledgetranslation.net/calculator)) provides you with free online calculators for determining things like number needed to treat (NNT), relative risk, and odds ratio. You can take information from a study you are reading and plug it into the calculators to help expand your understanding of it and its applicability to practice (e.g., calculating NNT). C) Critical Appraisal Skills Programme (CASP) Appraisal Tools CASP offers 8 free critical appraisal tools to help you quickly and easily assess studies you are reading, including RCT's, cohort studies and even economic evaluations. ( [https://casp-uk.net/casp-tools-checklists/](https://casp-uk.net/casp-tools-checklists/)) D) Evidence in Medicine and Evidence-Based Medicine An article hosted online by the Ottawa Hospital Research Institute, provides you with an extensive history and explanation of evidence-based medicine (EBM). This article provides you with additional context and information for understanding EBM at a deeper level. ( [http://www.ohri.ca/newsroom/seminars/SeminarUploads/1825%5CWorall%20-%20Evidence%20in%20Medicine%20and%20EBM.pdf](http://www.ohri.ca/newsroom/seminars/SeminarUploads/1825%5CWorall%20-%20Evidence%20in%20Medicine%20and%20EBM.pdf)) A) National Collaborating Centre for Methods and Tools (NCCMT) Learning Modules The NCCMT is an initiative supported by McMaster University to help promote and cultivate a culture of evidence-informed decision making in public health. While geared towards the public health discipline, they have a number of resources that are applicable for research-oriented clinicians, specifically their online learning modules ( [https://www.nccmt.ca/learning-modules](https://www.nccmt.ca/learning-modules)). The learning modules are free, and the majority provide you with a certificate of completion. Each module ranges from 2-4 hours to complete and includes step-by-step teaching. Module Examples: - Introduction to Evidence-Informed Decision Making - Critical Appraisal of Intervention Studies - Critical Appraisal of Qualitative Studies B) Using PubMed in Evidence-Based Practice (Training Course) PubMed offers a free 30-minute training course online for using their database in evidence-based practice. By clicking "next" at the bottom right of the page, it will take you through different content, including text, videos, and scenarios to help sharpen your skills. ( [https://www.nlm.nih.gov/oet/ed/pubmed/pubmed_in_ebp/index.html](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/oet/ed/pubmed/pubmed_in_ebp/index.html)) Research mailing lists and alerts are a useful tool for providing you with new and emerging information, without having to search for it yourself. Having a few set up can provide you with a steady stream of relevant and new research to review. We do recommend, however, to keep them to a select few as your inbox can easily become cluttered if you have too many active simultaneously. Most are free, however, some require registration and/or a fee for service. Resources: (Click the hyperlink to be brought to the website for more information) [Pubmed/NCBI Alerts](https://ncbiinsights.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2013/11/14/setting-up-automatic-ncbi-searches-and-new-record-alerts/) Free resource (requires the creation of an account). Alerts you about newly published studies based on the preferences and filters you set (e.g., receive the latest studies relating to green tea and cancer prevention). [Trip Database Automated Searches](https://www.tripdatabase.com/about) Free resource if using basic account/registration ("Premium" paid options available). Email each month identifying new research based on your clinical specialty and/or topics of interest. [NATURE News & Alerts](https://idp.nature.com/register/natureuser?redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Fmy-account%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe-journal%3Flist-id%3D1%26journal-link%3Dhttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Flatest-news) Registration is free. Provides access and alerts about news article style summaries of research and updates within the scientific community. [National Library of Medicine Email Lists](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/listserv/emaillists.html) Free service, no account required for most. Simply add your email to the mailing list and receive emailed information regarding a number of topics (chosen from a list of options). [Medscape Newsletters & Alerts](https://www.medscape.com/today) Free account/registration required. Receive information about medical news, clinical references and educations resources. [Examine.com Subscription Feature](https://examine.com/subscriptions-info/) Paid membership comes with access to summaries of the latest research pertaining to integrative medicine. [Natural Medicine Journal Updates](https://www.naturalmedicinejournal.com/) Free subscription service to
